content:
• Friday, February 17, 2017
  • OCN

    Ocwen settles with CA; shares +3% after hours

    • The settlement means Ocwen (NYSE:OCN) will again be able acquire MSRs on California homes, and the exit of the costly independent auditor.
    • It doesn't come cheap though - Ocwen will pay a $25M fine (already reserved for) and another $198M in debt forgiveness through mortgage modifications over the next three years.
    • Shares +3.24% in busy after hours action.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:00 PM | 46 Comments
  • TEUM

    Pareteum sets 1-for-25 reverse split

    • Pareteum (TEUM -2.1%), having slipped below $1/share for the past few years, has set a 1-for-25 reverse stock split.
    • Shares are off 7.1% after hours.
    • That's the biggest reverse authorized by stockholders last summer. The move will ensure compliance with NYSE minimum-bid requirements, Chairman Hal Turner says, adding that the move is the next step in ongoing restructuring.
    • The move will be effective after next Friday's close and common stock will trade split-adjusted when the market opens Feb. 27.
    • Pareteum is the former Elephant Talk Communications, which took on its new name and some new leadership (in CEO Vic Bozzo) Nov. 1.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:05 PM | 1 Comment

  • PAH-OLD

    Bloomberg: Platform Specialty Products considering company split

    • Platform Specialty Products (PAH-OLD +4.2%) spikes following a Bloomberg report that the chemical company is exploring strategic options including separating its agricultural and industrial businesses.
    • A split could pave the way for a sale of the agrichemical business, which PAH has built up through $4.9B of acquisitions over the past four years, according to the report.
    • The decision to explore options would reflect a view inside the company that its two distinct businesses are not correctly valued by the market.

  • AET

    Aetna authorizes $4B repurchase, declares $0.50 per share quarterly dividend

    • Quarterly dividend, doubled from prior level, payable April 28 to shareholders of record April 13.

  • S

    Sprint, T-Mobile spike on report SoftBank to pursue carrier merger

    • Sprint (NYSE:S) has jumped into positive ground on a Reuters report that parent SoftBank (OTCPK:SFTBY) is preparing to approach Deutsche Telekom (OTCQX:DTEGY) to discuss merging Sprint with T-Mobile (NASDAQ:TMUS).
    • Sprint is up 1.8% after trading down all day; T-Mobile has jumped 3.9%.
    • Sources tell Reuters that SoftBank is willing to give up control of Sprint to clinch the deal.
    • The two parents can't discuss getting the kids together just yet due to anti-collusion rules around the still-in-effect FCC spectrum auction, but they're expected to get together once it closes, likely in April.
    • Updated 3:08 p.m.: All four stocks have moved from negative to positive in U.S. trading: S +3.7%; TMUS +3.8%; OTCPK:SFTBY +1.6%; OTCQX:DTEGY +1.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:37 PM | 249 Comments
  • MAXR

    DigitalGlobe spikes into halt on reports of buyout talks

    • DigitalGlobe (DGI) is on a halt after reports that MacDonald Dettwiler (MDDWF) is in talks to buy the firm.
    • The deal could value the company at $2B-$3B, Dow Jones reports -- a solid premium for a company that closed yesterday with a market capitalization of about $1.84B.
    • Shares were up 14.4% before the halt, to $33.85, while valuation of the merger talk suggests they still have room to run perhaps into the $40s.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:24 PM | 2 Comments
  • AAN

    Double-digit drop for Aaron's after weak guidance

    • Shares of Aaron's (AAN -10.4%) trade lower after the company's Q4 EPS came in well-ahead of the consensus estimate, but sales growth numbers disappointed.
    • Same-store sales fell at company-owned locations, but adjusted EBITDA was higher than a year ago.
    • Cost-cutting and some weaning of underperforming stores helped pad the EBIDTA mark.
    • The company's guidance for 2017 EPS came in lower than anticipated.
    • Previously: More on Aaron's Q4 results (Feb. 17)
    • Previously: Aaron's beats by $0.06, misses on revenue (Feb. 17)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:09 PM
  • P

    Pandora +2.8% as FBN sees Sirius XM buyout clues in Buffett 13F

    • Pandora Media (NYSE:P) is up 2.8% after FBN Securities' Robert Routh sees greater potential for a previously discussed Sirius XM (SIRI +0.3%) buyout, thanks in part to the Oracle of Omaha.
    • Berkshire Hathaway's 13F showed Warren Buffett's firm took a position in Sirius XM, 67% owned by Liberty through its Liberty Sirius XM Group (LSXMA +0.5%).
    • The fact that Buffett is invested in both Liberty Sirius and Sirius XM shows he's leveraged to Sirius XM's upside, says Routh, and "Although some may not read into this, we do ... as Buffett and his team at BRK must see material upside in SIRI equity from Q4 2016 levels (and in LSXM as well) or they would have not taken the new position but conversely would have divested their sizeable position in LSXM.”
    • Speculation about a Sirius XM/Pandora combination fired up last year as Liberty's Greg Maffei floated the idea of buying into streaming music via Pandora, and the latter's shares spiked again in the late fall as merger chatter increased again.
    • Marking SIRI equity to market, Routh figures Liberty Sirius is trading at a discount to per-share NAV, and therefore "LSXM could look to buy Pandora using its equity as deal currency IF Pandora’s Board would agree to value LSXM at its fair value in any such deal of $48.59 rather than at its market value." It's a deal Pandora shareholders should take, at least in theory, he says.
    • And then "having all of SIRI (LSXM and SIRI) and P in the same place in an asset backed security would also justify a much higher public market valuation multiple than that presently ascribed to SIRI or P."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:07 PM | 65 Comments

  • ANET

    Goldman an outlier as analysts praise Arista Networks quarter

    • Arista Networks (NYSE:ANET) is skying today, up 18.5% and reaching a new all-time high after a stellar quarter that featured a sunny outlook and with analysts lining up with price target increases.
    • Most analysts, anyway: Goldman Sachs is sticking with a Sell rating, crediting the strong quarter to Microsoft "pulling forward demand into 2016 to ensure adequate supply." It's a risky period of execution for Arista, Simona Jankowski says, and that's not fully accounted for in the valuation.
    • Meanwhile, Needham raised its price target to $130 from $110, implying nearly 10% upside. Stifel Nicolaus boosted its target to $125 from $102.
    • Jefferies has a price target of $100 -- even with yesterday's close but below today's higher quotes -- but upgraded the stock to Hold from Underperform, noting "We now believe that — in the highest-probability scenario — Arista's legal problems won't affect their core business in any significant way."
    • Earnings call slides
     
     
     
     
    | 1:37 PM | 4 Comments
  • TTMI

    TTM Technologies downgraded to Neutral at J.P. Morgan, valuation cited

    • From Overweight prior, firm notes 160%+ year-basis gains.
    • Though expecting end-market demand to remain sound in FY 2017, views limited upcoming catalysts. Further (analyst Paul Coster): "In short, we like this company and no-nonsense management team, so we recommend investors stay in the stock, but at the current stock price we think there are better risk-reward trade-offs elsewhere in our coverage universe."
    • Price target $18, unchanged.
    • TTM Technologies (NASDAQ:TTMI) $16.74, -4.12%.

  • NAK

    Northern Dynasty fires back at short seller who called company "worthless"

    • North Dynasty Minerals (NAK +3.5%) rebuts a short seller’s report that called the company "worthless," slamming the charges as "unfounded" and containing "numerous errors and unsupported speculation" that demonstrate a lack of understanding of the company’s business.
    • NAK shares had soared more than 300% since the November election on hopes that the miner's controversial Pebble copper-gold project in Alaska would be approved under a new president, but Kerrisdale Capital Management said the project is "not commercially viable" and would require an investment so large “that it would actually destroy value.”
    • NAK says other mining companies are turning profits from mining lower grade ore within a few hundred miles of its project, and that its resource and reserve claims have been certified by independent qualified experts who attest to the accuracy of the company's reports.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:47 PM | 11 Comments

  • PERF

    Perfumania said to explore strategic options

    • Perfumania Holdings (PERF -6.6%) is exploring strategic alternatives, sources tell  Reuters.
    • Among the options being considered is a change to the capital structure at the company.
    • Shares of Perfumania are down 29% over the last 52 weeks.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:43 PM | 2 Comments
  • CDMO

    Peregrine continues liquid biopsy test data-stoked up move, shares ahead 34%

    • Peregrine Pharmaceuticals (PPHM +34%) heads north on a 7x surge in volume. Shares have more than doubled since the company announced encouraging results from a proof-of-concept study of a new cancer detection platform based on cell-derived vesicles called exosomes. The data were published recently in the journal Oncotarget.
    • The test was able to distinguish between healthy subjects and patients with ovarian tumors based on the level of exosomes in plasma samples that contained an amino acid called phosphatidylserine (PS). In addition, investigators were able to distinguish between benign and malignant tumors based on an analysis of PS-positive exosome levels. Cancer diagnostic tests performed on body fluids (blood, serum, plasma, urine, cerebrospinal fluid) are called liquid biopsies.
    • The company is working on commercializing the technology.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:05 PM | 51 Comments

  • GST

    Gastar Exploration +10% on $425M financing deal with Ares

    • Gastar Exploration (GST +10.8%) secures a securities purchase agreement with funds managed by affiliates of Ares Management that provides for $425M in new financing.
    • GST says it plans to use the funds to fully repay its existing $70M revolving credit facility and redeem $325M in senior secured notes due May 2018.
    • GST also announces well results from recent STACK drilling activities, saying it has drilled and completed eight wells and has drilled but not yet completed another eight wells.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:57 AM | 26 Comments
  • SCG

    SCANA making contingency plans for South Carolina reactors

    • SCANA (SCG -2.4%) says it is drawing up contingency plans in case Toshiba cannot finish the job of building two nuclear power reactors in South Carolina.
    • SCG said late yesterday that it was placing software and design information for the unfinished reactors into escrow, which could allow it to hire a new engineering and construction firm if Toshiba defaults or stops work.
    • The announcement was the first indication that SCG is seriously preparing for the possibility that Toshiba might not be able to complete the work.
    • Officials from Westinghouse, Toshiba's nuclear construction division, met earlier this week with SCG and the companies said they expected to finish the South Carolina facility, although the completion date was pushed back to 2020.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:33 AM | 6 Comments
  • WDAY

    Workday +4.1%; upgraded to Overweight at Piper Jaffray

  • ARQL

    ArQule's lead product candidate tivantinib flunks late-stage liver cancer study; shares down 16%

    • Thinly traded nano cap ArQule (ARQL -16.3%) slumps on more than double normal volume in response its announcement that lead product candidate tivantinib failed to beat best supportive care in a 340-subject Phase 3 study, METIV-HCC, in a second-line setting in patients with MET-overexpressing, inoperable hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
    • The primary endpoint was overall survival. Secondary endpoints included progression-free survival and safety.
    • Complete results will be submitted for presentation at an upcoming scientific conference.
    • Tivantinib is an orally-administered selective inhibitor of MET, a receptor of tyrosine kinase. ArQule is co-developing the candidate with Daiichi Sankyo (OTCPK:DSNKY).
     
     
     
     
    | 10:01 AM
  • AAN

    More on Aaron's Q4 results

    • Aaron's (AAN -9.6%) reports same-store revenue declined 5.8% in Q4.
    • Segment revenues: Sales & Lease Ownership: $446.32M (-12.5%); Progressive: $323.96M (+17.5%); DAMI: $7.54M (+164.9%); Franchise: $13.39M (-13.3%); Manufacturing: $22.71M (-18.8%).
    • Adjusted EBITDA grew 9.6% to $73.85M.
    • Customer counts on a same-store basis slipped 4.2%.
    • Total Aaron's customers at the end of the quarter squeezed 6% to 973K.
    • Total store count -67 Q/Q to 1,864.
    • FY2017 Guidance: Total revenues: ~$3.1B to $3.31B; Aaron's Business revenue: ~$1.68B to $1.78B; Progressive revenue: ~$1.40B to $1.50B; DAMI revenue: ~$25M to $35M; Adjusted EBITDA: ~$320M to $353M; Aaron's Business EBITDA : ~$155M to $170M; Progressive EBITDA: $170M to $185M; Diluted EPS: $1.85 to $2.10; Adjusted Diluted EPS: $2.15 to $2.40; Capital expenditure: $60M to $80M.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:48 AM

  • UNH

    U.S. DOJ sues UnitedHealth Group over alleged Medicare overcharges; shares slump 3% premarket

    • UnitedHealth Group (NYSE:UNH) eases 3% premarket on increased volume in response to a lawsuit filed in a Los Angeles district court by the Department of Justice accusing the company of overcharging Medicare, specifically Medicare Advantage, by "hundreds of millions and, likely, billions of dollars" over more than a decade.
    • Unsurprisingly, the company disputes the charges. Spokesman Matthew Burns says, “We reject these more than five-year-old claims and will contest them vigorously." He adds that the company served millions of Medicare Advantage members and was “proud of the access to quality health care we provided and confident we complied with the program rules.”
    • The suit originated with whistleblower Benjamin Poehling, a former executive who filed a complaint under the False Claims Act.
    • Source: NYT
     
     
     
     
    | 9:09 AM | 43 Comments
  • CPB

    Campbell Soup lower post FQ2 results

    • Campbell Soup (NYSE:CPB) reports comparable organic sales declined 2% in FQ2, driven by lower volume and higher promotional spending.
    • Total volume and mix fell 1% for the period.
    • Revenue by segments: Americas simple meals and beverages: $1.231(flat); Global biscuits and snacks: $680M (flat); Campbell fresh: $260M (-8%).
    • Adjusted gross margin rate improved 70 bps to 38%.
    • Adjusted EBIT flat Y/Y at 19.2%.
    • FY2017 Guidance: Net sales: 0 to 1%; Adjusted EBIT: +1% to +4%; Adjusted EPS: $3 to $3.09 (+2% to +5%).
    • CPB -3.1% premarket.

Each ADS purchased will include one unregistered 5 1/2-year warrant to purchase one ADS at $4.10. Closing date is February 23.

  • DIN

    Applebee's boss to step down

    • DineEquity (NYSE:DIN) announces that Julia Stewart will retire as chief executive officer and interim president of the Applebee's business unit on March 1.
    • The board of directors has named current lead director Richard Dahl to serve as interim CEO and chairman.
    • Source: Press Release
    • DIN -2.03% premarket to $65.20.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:39 AM | 15 Comments
  • CELG

    Celgene's ozanimod successful in late-stage MS study; shares up a fraction premarket

    • A Phase 3 clinical trial, SUNBEAM, evaluating Celgene's (NASDAQ:CELG) ozanimod in patients with relapsing multiple sclerosis (RMS) met its primary endpoint of showing a statistically valid reduction in annualized relapse rate (ARR) compared to weekly interferon [Biogen's (NASDAQ:BIIB) Avonex].
    • The 1,346-subject study assessed two oral doses of ozanimod (0.5 mg and 1.0 mg) in RMS patients for at least one year. Safety and tolerability data were consistent with earlier Phase 2 studies (RADIANCE and TOUCHSTONE).
    • Data from the confirmatory Phase 3 RADIANCE trial are expected next quarter. Regulatory submissions are on tap for year end.
    • Ozanimod is an oral, once-daily selective sphingosine 1-phosphate 1 and 5 receptor modulator being developed for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. It diminishes the activity of autoreactive lymphocytes (white blood cells) which is the cause of many types of autoimmune disorders. Celgene obtained the rights to the drug via its acquisition of Receptos.
    • Shares are up a fraction premarket on light volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:36 AM | 2 Comments
  • K

    Food sector M&A news sends Kellogg lower

    • Kellogg (NYSE:K) is down 2.82% in premarket trading on shifting M&A sands in the food sector.
    • Kraft Heinz is pursuing a merger with Unilever and CNBC reported that 3G is looking outside of consumer packaged goods for its next big deal.
    • Previously: Mondelez slides with Kraft and 3G looking elsewhere (Feb. 17)

  • GIS

    General Mills updates FY17 guidance

    • General Mills (NYSE:GIS) lowers its forecast for FY17 in reaction to competitive pressure in the U.S. yogurt and soup categories,
    • The company expects to deliver an adjusted operating profit margin of at least 18% in FY17, up at least 120 bps Y/Y.
    • Organic net sales are now expected to fall about 4% vs. -3% to -4% prior view.
    • Total segment operating profit growth in constant currency is expected to range from -1% to +1%.
    • FY17 EPS is expected to increase 5 % to 7%. The company expects free cash flow to increase at a mid single-digit rate.
    • Source: Press Release
    • Previously: Kraft-Unilever news could impact CPB, HSY and GIS (Feb. 17)
    • Previously: Mondelez slides with Kraft and 3G looking elsewhere (Feb. 17)
    • GIS -4.13% premarket to $59.00. Kraft Heinz-Unilever news is also in the mix this morning.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:24 AM | 4 Comments
  • MDLZ

    Mondelez slides with Kraft and 3G looking elsewhere

    • Shares of Mondelez International (NASDAQ:MDLZ) are down 5.41% in premarket action after Kraft Heinz (NASDAQ:KHC) sets its sights on Unilever.

    • Investors are still bidding up Kraft, shares are up 4.84% to $91.50 off this morning's developments.
    • Previously: Unilever passes on Kraft Heinz merger (Feb. 17)

  • RUTH

    More on Ruth's Hospitality's Q4

    • Ruth's Hospitality (NASDAQ:RUTH) reports company-owned comparable restaurant sales flat Y/Y in Q4, consisted of an average check increase of 2.3%.
    • Traffic slipped 2.2% for the period.
    • Total restaurant sales rose 2.4% to $101.21M.
    • Franchise income increased 6.1% to $4.8M.
    • Average unit weekly company-owned sales increased 0.3% to $114.5K.
    • Food and beverage costs as a percentage of restaurant sales for the company decreased 180 bps to 28.7%, primarily driven by a 6.4% decline in total beef costs.
    • Operating margin rate improved 160 bps to 14%.
    • FY2017 Guidance: Food and beverage costs: 29% to 31% of restaurant sales; Restaurant operating expenses: 47% to 49% of restaurant sales; Marketing and advertising costs: 2.9% to 3.1% of total revenues; G&A expenses: $32M to $34M; Effective tax rate: 31% to 34%; Capital expenditure: $24M to $26M; Diluted shares outstanding: 31.3M to 32M.

  • AZN

    AstraZeneca's Lynparza beats chemo in late-stage breast cancer study; shares up 2% premarket

    • AstraZeneca (NYSE:AZN) is up 2% premarket on average volume in response to its announcement of positive results from a Phase 3 clinical trial, OLYMPIAD, assessing LYNPARZA (olaparib) compared to standard-of-care chemotherapy for the treatment of patients with HER2-negative, BRCA1- or BRCA2-positive breast cancer.
    • Patients receiving LYNPARZA showed a statistically significant improvement in progression-free survival (PFS) compared to chemotherapy (capecitabine, vinorelbine or eribulin).
    • EVP, Global Medicines Development and Chief Medical Officer Sean Bohen says, "These results are positive news for patients with BRCA-mutated metastatic breast cancer, a disease with a high unmet need, and are the first positive Phase III data for a PARP inhibitor beyond ovarian cancer. This is highly encouraging for the development of our broad portfolio which aims to treat multiple cancers by targeting DNA damage response pathways."
    • The results will be submitted for presentation at an upcoming medical meeting. Regulatory applications are being prepared.
    • LYNPARZA is currently approved to treat BRCA-positive ovarian cancer.

  • MESO

    Mesoblast's cell therapy candidate MPC-300-IV shows positive effect in mid-stage study in treatment-resistant rheumatoid arthritis

    • A Phase 2 clinical trial assessing Mesoblast's (NASDAQ:MESO) allogeneic cell therapy candidate MPC-300-IV in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) who have not responded to anti-Tumor Necrosis Factor (TNF) therapy [e.g., AbbVie's Humira (adalimumab)] showed a durable improvement in symptoms, physical function and disease activity with no safety signals observed.
    • The study enrolled 48 patients with active RA who were on a stable regimen of methotrexate and had an inadequate response to at least one anti-TNF agent. 63% (n=30/48) has received 1 - 2 biologic agents. Participants were randomized to receive a single infusion of 1M Mesenchymal Precursor Cells (MPCs)/kg (n=16), 2M MPCs/kg (n=16) or placebo (n=16). The primary study period was 12 weeks and the total study duration was 52 weeks.
    • Both doses of MPC-300-IV outperformed placebo at both week 12 and week 39 as measured by ACR20/50/70 (ACR20 = 20% improvement in RA symptoms). The 2M-cell cohort showed the greatest response. At week 12, for example, 27% of the 2M-cell group achieved ACR70 compared to 0% for placebo. The proportion was 36% in the subgroup (n=11) who had received 1 - 2 biologics. The treatment effect was maintained through week 39.
    • The clinical development of MPC-300-IV is ongoing.

  • EDIT

    CRISPR/Cas9 fight could be far from over

    • *Despite the initial reaction from investors that stoked Wednesday's nearly 30% spike in Editas Medicine (NASDAQ:EDIT), the dispute over who owns what related to patents covering gene editing technology CRISPR/Cas9 could drag on for some time. IP attorney Eric Nielsen of Snell & Wilmer added his perspective on the situation in an interview yesterday evening. 
    • The PTAB's decision to end the interference proceeding stating the claim sets filed by UC-Berkeley and Broad/MIT are "patently distinct" means that both parties are in a position to receive their respective patents and, when issued, could decide to renew their dispute which could drag on for years. Mr. Nielsen says a more pragmatic approach could be to execute a cross-licensing agreement that includes mutually acceptable royalties on future CRISPR-based therapies, which is where the real money is. 
    • One reason for the pragmatism is the likelihood of overlapping patent rights. UC's patent claims are more general while Broad's are specific to the application of the technology to eukaryotic cells, hence PTAB's position. 
    • Mr. Nielsen adds, "Should UC decide to continue the fight, it could file an appeal at the Federal Circuit and even petition the Supreme Court. Once new patents are issued (UC has at least 11 applications pending, some patents could be issued in the coming months) a Post-Grant or Inter Partes review could be initiated by Broad." 
    • Intellia Therapeutics (NASDAQ:NTLA) rallied 7% yesterday  while CRISPR Therapeutics (NASDAQ:CRSP) jumped 17%. EDIT was up 2%. 
     
     
     
     
    | 6:32 AM | 9 Comments

    S&P warning sends Toshiba tumbling

    • Toshiba (OTCPK:TOSYY) shares sank 10% overnight after S&P Global said it could slash the conglomerate's rating several notches if financial support from lenders includes any form of debt restructuring.
    • Any further downgrade would prompt banks to charge Toshiba even higher rates for credit, at a time when it's dealing with a crippling nuclear writedown and still working to recover from a financial scandal in 2015.
